rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:1–2
rsbNotes.text: 1:1, 2 Opening salutation, including sender, recipient, and benediction.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:1
rsbNotes.text:
1:1 apostle of Christ Jesus. One sent out as an official representative of Christ (2 Cor. 1:1 note).

by the will of God. Paul identifies the One who commissioned him (1 Cor. 1:1; 2 Cor. 1:1; Eph. 1:1; Col. 1:1).

according to the promise of the life that is in Christ Jesus. The role of the apostle is to proclaim the life that is in Christ (1 Tim. 1:16 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:2
rsbNotes.text:
1:2 beloved child. See Introduction to 1 Timothy: Date and Occasion; 1 Cor. 4:17 (cf. 1 Tim. 1:2).

Grace . . . our Lord. See note 1 Tim. 1:2.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:3–5
rsbNotes.text:
1:3–5 As in most of his letters (the exceptions are Galatians, 1 Timothy, and Titus), Paul follows his salutation with a section giving thanks to God for the recipients of the letter. Here he focuses on his relationship with Timothy and his confidence in Timothy’s faith.

I long to see you. Paul anticipates his request in 4:9, 21.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:5
rsbNotes.text: 1:5 Lois . . . Eunice. These women are named only here in the New Testament. See Introduction to 1 Timothy: Date and Occasion.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:6–14
rsbNotes.text: 1:6–14 Paul moves into the body of letter. As he exhorts Timothy to boldness and faithfulness, Paul discusses the gospel and his own role in proclaiming it.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:6
rsbNotes.text:
1:6 fan into flame the gift of God. This strong expression suggests that Timothy was being less forceful than he should have been in using the spiritual gift God had given him.

laying on of my hands. See note 1 Tim. 1:18.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:7
rsbNotes.text: 1:7 fear. Or, “cowardice.” This strong expression was necessary, given Timothy’s natural timidity and the gravity of his situation.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:8
rsbNotes.text: 1:8 me his prisoner. Paul is in prison in Rome (2:9; Introduction: Date and Occasion).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:9
rsbNotes.text:
1:9 to a holy calling. The goal of God’s election and calling is the sanctification of His people (Eph. 1:4).

not . . . grace. This is a marvelous affirmation that salvation is by grace, not by human merit (Eph. 2:8, 9).

because of his own purpose. God’s decree of redemption is based solely on His own purpose and good pleasure. Elsewhere, this divine purpose is identified as mercy (Titus 3:5) and love (Eph. 1:4, 5).

before the ages began. An affirmation that the divine decree of redemption through Christ is from eternity (Eph. 1:4; Titus 1:2; 1 Pet. 1:20; Rev. 13:8).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:10
rsbNotes.text:
1:10 our Savior Christ Jesus. Christ is the Mediator of the covenant of grace (Titus 1:4; 2:13; 3:6).

who abolished death and brought life and immortality to light. That is, through His death and resurrection (Heb. 2:14, 15; Rev. 1:18).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:11
rsbNotes.text: 1:11 preacher. See 1 Tim. 2:7.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:12
rsbNotes.text:
1:12 I suffer. Paul is in prison (v. 8; 2:9).

I am not ashamed. Having exhorted Timothy not to be ashamed to speak out for Christ (v. 8), Paul presents himself as a model of boldness in the face of suffering (2:8–10; 3:10, 11).

that Day. Judgment Day (v. 18; 4:8).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:13
rsbNotes.text: 1:13 sound words. This theme runs throughout the Pastoral Letters (1 Tim. 1:10 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:14
rsbNotes.text: 1:14 the good deposit entrusted to you. See note 1 Tim. 6:20.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:15–18
rsbNotes.text: 1:15–18 Paul’s concern that Timothy be faithful leads him to set forth specific examples of unfaithfulness and faithfulness.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:15
rsbNotes.text:
1:15 all. Paul is probably writing with intentional exaggeration to make sure his readers see the extent of the disloyalty.

Asia. A Roman province across the Aegean Sea from Greece and today part of western Turkey. Ephesus, where Timothy was serving as Paul’s representative, was the leading city of this province.

Phygelus and Hermogenes. Not mentioned elsewhere in the New Testament. Probably Paul mentions them because he had counted on their support.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:16
rsbNotes.text: 1:16 Onesiphorus. A member of the church at Ephesus who distinguished himself through his loyalty to Paul (v. 18; cf. 4:19).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:17
rsbNotes.text: 1:17 when he arrived in Rome. Onesiphorus may have come to Rome to aid Paul.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 1:18
rsbNotes.text: 1:18 that Day. The Day of Judgment (v. 12; 4:8).
